message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of palpable gonads and a karyotype of 46,XX suggests that the newborn has congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation. CAH can result in ambiguous genitalia, and it is more common in females than males. Defective androgen receptors and 5-alpha-reductase deficiency are causes of male pseudohermaphroditism. Defective migration of GnRH releasing neurons results in Kallmann syndrome, which is associated with anosmia and hypogonadism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation. CAH can cause virilization in females and can also affect the development of the genitals. Defective androgen receptors would result in male pseudohermaphroditism, while defective migration of GnRH-releasing neurons would result in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Deficiency of 5-alpha-reductase would result in incomplete masculinization of external genitalia in males.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of palpable gonads and ambiguous genitalia suggests a disorder of sex development. Among the options, exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation is the most likely cause, as 5-alpha-reductase deficiency and defective androgen receptors typically present with more specific genital abnormalities, and defective migration of GnRH releasing neurons would not result in ambiguous genitalia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn has ambiguous genitalia, which suggests a disorder of sexual development. Among the options, exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation can cause virilization of female genitalia. Defective androgen receptors can cause androgen insensitivity syndrome, but this would result in normal female external genitalia. Defective migration of GnRH releasing neurons can result in delayed puberty, but would not cause ambiguous genitalia. Deficiency of 5-alpha-reductase can cause incomplete virilization of male genitalia, but would not explain the absence of palpable gonads.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn has ambiguous genitalia and no palpable gonads suggesting that the baby has some form of intersex condition. The 46,XX karyotype rules out options A and B. Option C would present with male external genitalia. Exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation can lead to ambiguous genitalia and is consistent with the presentation of this newborn.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ambiguous genitalia in a 46,XX fetus suggests exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation. Defective androgen receptors, defective migration of GnRH releasing neurons, and deficiency of 5-alpha-reductase are all causes of abnormal genital development, but they typically present differently with differing karyotypes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation described suggests exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation, leading to ambiguous genitalia. Defective androgen receptors would lead to a female phenotype, while a deficiency of 5-alpha-reductase would lead to ambiguous genitalia in individuals with XY karyotypes. Defective migration of GnRH-releasing neurons would affect puberty and fertility, rather than fetal development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a disorder of sexual development (DSD) with ambiguous genitalia, and the most likely cause is exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation. Defective androgen receptors result in testicular feminization, whereas defective migration of GnRH releasing neurons or deficiency of 5-alpha-reductase (which converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone) results in incomplete masculinization of the genitalia, but not necessarily ambiguous genitalia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn girl can be explained by exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation. Defective androgen receptors and deficiency of 5-alpha-reductase would result in masculinization of genitalia, while defective migration of GnRH-releasing neurons would result in hypogonadism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of ambiguous genitalia suggests intersex or disorders of sex development (DSD), and the absence of palpable gonads indicates that the newborn has a female phenotype. Among the options, exposure to excessive androgenic steroids during gestation, such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), is the most likely cause of DSD in this case. Defective androgen receptors cause androgen insensitivity syndrome, which typically presents with a female phenotype but with normal gonads. Defective migration of GnRH releasing neurons or deficiency of 5-alpha-reductase may cause other types of DSD but are less likely in this case.
